author: Mark Leevan
title: Why 'The Walk' movie may make you vomit
text:
Play The Walk is making people vomit sony.com If press screenings of The Walk movie are any indication, people may be vomiting in movie theaters en masse.
The Walk, is a film directed by Robert Zemeckis and chronicles story of Philippe Petit’s famous tightrope walk between the World Trade Center Towers According to the New York Post , there have been several incidences of people vomiting while watching the movie in 3D.
Journalist Mark Harris sent out the following tweet.
“Reports of guys vomiting in the Alice Tully men’s rm post-The Walk: True. Witnessed it/came close. Bad visual trigger for vertigo sufferers.”
The Walk was shot in 3D, which makes the high-altitude scenes seem very real for viewers — so much so that movie-goers in theaters across the nation have literally vomited.
The press screening tweets from people who saw the move in theaters, a lot of movie-goers reported feeling physically ill.
“Right behind us, there’s a 50-foot drop, which is hilarious for this type of movie where we’re on top of towers the whole time — and this is the most petrified I’ve ever been in my entire life,” comedian Ben Schwartz jokingly admitted during The Walk press conference.
The Walk has vertigo -inducing scenes. Webmd.com says: Vertigo is a sensation of spinning. If you have these dizzy spells, you might feel like you are spinning or that the world around you is spinning.
Vertigo is often triggered by a change in the position of your head. Or in the case of The Walk movie, your brain is tricked into thinking your head has changed positions.
People with vertigo typically describe it as feeling like they are:
Spinning Tilting Swaying Unbalanced Pulled to one direction According to The Hollywood Reporter, Zemeckis began developing the film after reading the children’s book, The Man Who Walked Between the Towers. He was interested in developing a story that would use 3D to advance the story when brought to the big screen. “I thought it had all the elements to make a compelling movie,” Zemeckis explained, “that lets you in to see what all the real characters were thinking. The thing I always wanted to do was present the walk itself, and of course that can’t be done in the documentary because there’s no video footage of the walk ever recorded. … The goal was to evoke the feeling of vertigo. We worked really hard to put the audience up on those towers and on the wire,” he said.
If vomit in movie theaters is an indication, he has succeeded. Now the question is, will movie-goers go to a movie that literally makes them sick?
